# Papers

## Effect sizes


[Hedges, L. V. (2008). What are effect sizes and why do we need them?. Child Development Perspectives, 2(3), 167-171.](https://srcd.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/j.1750-8606.2008.00060.x?casa_token=hrW46KhivQ4AAAAA%3AUXWiARQ2gw2nDby94QWoZZaLyn-8bkPd-RgEzEBZL-6_LOA4Ca0_bjoCqJ6MZjGS35Dt5elGE6_v) 

## Assumption underlying pooling effect sizes

[Rice, K., Higgins, J. P., & Lumley, T. (2018). A re-evaluation of fixed effect (s) meta-analysis. JR Stat Soc Ser A Stat Soc, 181(1), 205-27.](https://rss.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/rssa.12275)


[Higgins, J. P., Thompson, S. G., & Spiegelhalter, D. J. (2009). A re‐evaluation of random‐effects meta‐analysis. Journal of the Royal Statistical Society: Series A (Statistics in Society), 172(1), 137-159.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2667312/)



## Measures of heterogeneity

[Higgins, J. P., & Thompson, S. G. (2002). Quantifying heterogeneity in a meta‐analysis. Statistics in medicine, 21(11), 1539-1558.](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12111919/)

                
## Dependent Effect Sizes 

### Multivariate meta-analysis

[Becker, B. J. (2000). Multivariate meta-analysis. In Handbook of applied multivariate statistics and mathematical modeling (pp. 499-525). Academic Press.](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780126913606500185)

### Robust variance estimation

[Hedges, L. V., Tipton, E., & Johnson, M. C. (2010). Robust variance estimation in meta‐regression with dependent effect size estimates. Research synthesis methods, 1(1), 39-65.](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26056092/)

            
[Tipton, E. (2015). Small sample adjustments for robust variance estimation with meta-regression. Psychological methods, 20(3), 375.](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24773356/) 


[Tipton, E., & Pustejovsky, J. E. (2015). Small-sample adjustments for tests of moderators and model fit using robust variance estimation in meta-regression. Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics, 40(6), 604-634.](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.3102/1076998615606099)               


[Tanner-Smith, E.E., Tipton, E. & Polanin, J.R. Handling Complex Meta-analytic Data Structures Using Robust Variance Estimates: a Tutorial in R. J Dev Life Course Criminology 2, 85–112 (2016).](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40865-016-0026-5#citeas)



### RVE expanded working models 

[Pustejovsky, J. E., & Tipton, E. (2020). Meta-Analysis with Robust Variance Estimation: Expanding the Range of Working Models.](https://osf.io/preprints/metaarxiv/vyfcj/)


    
## Model Diagnostics

[Viechtbauer, W., & Cheung, M. W. L. (2010). Outlier and influence diagnostics for meta‐analysis. Research synthesis methods, 1(2), 112-125.](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrsm.11)


## Publication Bias

[Rodgers, M. A., & Pustejovsky, J. E. (2020). Evaluating meta-analytic methods to detect selective reporting in the presence of dependent effect sizes. Psychological methods.](https://osf.io/preprints/metaarxiv/vqp8u/)


[Mathur, M. B., & VanderWeele, T. J. (2020). Sensitivity analysis for publication bias in meta‐analyses. Journal of the Royal Statistical Society: Series C (Applied Statistics), 69(5), 1091-1119.](https://rss.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/rssc.12440)

## MetaSEM

[Cheung, M. W. L. (2015). metaSEM: An R package for meta-analysis using structural equation modeling. Frontiers in Psychology, 5, 1521.](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2014.01521/full)
